title: SB 1073
content: The people of the State of California enact the following. Section 17052 of the Revenue and Taxation Code is amended to allow an earned income tax credit against the "net tax" for taxable years starting January 1, 2015. The credit amount is determined based on Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code, adjusted by a factor specified in the annual Budget Act. The credit is only applicable when resources are allocated for oversight and auditing by the Franchise Tax Board. The earned income tax credit is only available when resources are allocated for oversight by the Franchise Tax Board. The credit percentage and phaseout percentage vary based on the number of qualifying children. The earned income amount and phaseout amount also differ depending on the number of qualifying children. Joint returns are not applicable for this credit. The earned income tax credit amounts vary based on the number of qualifying children, with different earned income and phaseout amounts for each scenario. Certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are modified for this credit, including adjustments for joint returns and place of abode. Additionally, the earned income amount is modified to $3,400. Section 32 of the Internal Revenue Code is modified for the earned income tax credit, including adjustments for place of abode and income amounts. Excess credit can be used to offset other tax liabilities and refunded to the taxpayer. The Franchise Tax Board may prescribe rules for implementing the tax credit, and refunds under this section are treated similarly to federal earned income refunds for determining eligibility for benefits. The Franchise Tax Board is exempt from certain reporting requirements for implementing the 2015 tax credit. The purpose of the California Earned Income Tax Credit is to reduce poverty, and the Board must report on the number of tax returns claiming the credit annually. The Franchise Tax Board must report annually on the number of tax returns claiming the California Earned Income Tax Credit, including details such as the average credit amount, distribution by dependents and income ranges, and estimates of families lifted out of deep poverty by the credit. The report is to be provided to various Senate and Assembly committees. The Franchise Tax Board will provide an annual report on the California Earned Income Tax Credit to several Senate and Assembly committees. The tax credit will be known as the California Earned Income Tax Credit and will apply to taxable years starting from January 1, 2016.
